comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -126,6 +126,7 @@ spec:
 | global.clusterAgentTokenSecret.keyName | KeyName is the key of the secret to use. |
 | global.clusterAgentTokenSecret.secretName | SecretName is the name of the secret. |
 | global.clusterName | ClusterName sets a unique cluster name for the deployment to easily scope monitoring data in the Datadog app. |
+| global.containerProcessStrategy.type | `type` sets a predetermined grouping of processes across containers. Two are supported at thist point: `singleProcessContainers`, default behavior, runs one process per container. `nonPrivilegedMultiProcessContainer`, runs non-privileged processes in a single container unless current configuration requires a privileged agent, for example `security-agent` or `system-probe` is required, fall back to singleProcessContainer Default: `singleProcessContainers` |
comment.body:
```suggestion
| global.containerProcessStrategy.type | `type` sets a predetermined grouping of processes across containers. The two supported groupings: `singleProcessContainers`, default behavior, runs one process per container. `nonPrivilegedMultiProcessContainer`, runs non-privileged processes in a single container unless current configuration requires a privileged agent. For example `security-agent` or `system-probe` is required, falls back to `singleProcessContainer` because it's the default. |
```

pull_request.title: Levan m/mono container
pull_request.body:
### What does this PR do?

Support of so called agent mono-container, controlled by `global.containerProcessModel.useMultiProcessContainer` property in DatadogAgent.

When enabled, if feature doesn't require `system-probe` or `security-agent` Operator will run non-privileged agents in a  single multi-process container. If property is disabled or `system-probe`, `security-agent` required, Operator will create single-process containers.


### Motivation

What inspired you to submit this pull request?

### Additional Notes

How to review?
Key changes in the PR are limited to multiple files. Majority of changes are feature updates, each being self-contained and tests.  
1. Start with CRD change.
2. Next `controllers/datadogagent/feature/types.go`. This defines an interface func `ManageMultuProcessNodeAgent`. This function is implemented by all features to support multi-process agent.
3. `controllers/datadogagent/feature/factory.go` this implements logic for checking `RequiredComponents` and `DatadogAgent` to determine weather to configure default containers (single-process ones) or to use multi-process agent.
4. `controllers/datadogagent/controller_reconcile_agent.go` this decides whether to configure each feature for single or multi-process container and call corresponding `Manage*` function.
5. `global.go`, `default.go` supporting multi-process container.
6. Each feature can be reviewed in isolation.
7. `controllers/datadogagent/controller_v2_test.go` implements controller test to verify how various feature settings determines which containers are created.


### Minimum Agent Versions

Are there minimum versions of the Datadog Agent and/or Cluster Agent required?

* Agent: vX.Y.Z
* Cluster Agent: vX.Y.Z

### Describe your test plan
1. Install Operator. 
8. Create manifest not requiring `system-probe` and `security-agent`.
  1. Apply manifest - confirm agent pod is created with 2 or 3 containers. 
  2. Add `global.containerProcessModel.useMultiProcessContainer: true` to manifest - confirm agents restart with single container.
  9. Update manifest to enabled `cws` feature - confirm agents restart with 4 or 5 containers.
  10. Set `global.containerProcessModel.useMultiProcessContainer: false` - confirm agents restart with same number of containers.
  11. Disable `cws` feature - confirm agents restart with 2 or 3 containers.
  12. Set `global.containerProcessModel.useMultiProcessContainer: true` - confirm agent restarts with single container.

### Checklist

- [ ] PR has at least one valid label: `bug`, `enhancement`, `refactoring`, `documentation`, `tooling`, and/or `dependencies`
- [ ] PR has a milestone or the `qa/skip-qa` label

pull_request.title: Adding Service Level Objective CRD and Controller
pull_request.body: ### What does this PR do? This pull request introduces the `DatadogSLO CRD` types and controller, addressing issue #684. ### Motivation As each organization scales, they gonna rely on many `SLOs`, each of the SLO's managed by individual teams. This situation has led to complexity in maintaining these `SLOs` with us as well. The introduction of the `DatadogSLO CRD` types and controller into `datadog-operator` aims to simplify this process, enabling us to create and manage our `SLOs` and `Monitors` using our `GitOps` tools. This feature is crucial as we scale and manage a growing number of SLOs across various teams. ### Additional Notes - The development of this feature was inspired by the `DatadogMonitor CRD` codebase, which has proven effective in similar use cases. - Shared Finalizer: A shared finalizer has been added to enhance code reusability. - Simplified Updating Status Conditions: The condition logic has been simplified and now uses Kubernetes utilities for better efficiency and code coverage. ### Describe your test plan Write there any instructions and details you may have to test your PR. - `kind cluster create` - `make buid` - `make IMG=test/operator:test docker-build` - `kubectl apply -f https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/releases/download/v1.8.0/cert-manager.yaml ` - `kind load docker-image test/operator:test` - `make IMG=test/operator:test deploy` - `kubectl apply -f examples/datadogslo/metric-example.yaml` ``` kubectl get datadogslos -n system NAME ID SYNC STATUS AGE example-slo 21e10346c75c5852a12214d1d89dd2c2 OK 2m53s ``` result in DD:

labels.name: editorial review
labels.description: Waiting on a more in-depth review

+// Unless explicitly stated otherwise all files in this repository are licensed
+// under the Apache License Version 2.0.
+// This product includes software developed at Datadog (https://www.datadoghq.com/).
+// Copyright 2016-present Datadog, Inc.
+
+package datadogslo
+
+import (
+	"context"
+	"strings"
+	"time"
+
+	"github.com/go-logr/logr"
+	corev1 "k8s.io/api/core/v1"
+	apiequality "k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/api/equality"
+	apierrors "k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/api/errors"
+	metav1 "k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/apis/meta/v1"
+	"k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/runtime"
+	"k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/types"
+	"k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/version"
+	"k8s.io/client-go/tools/record"
+	ctrl "sigs.k8s.io/controller-runtime"
+	"sigs.k8s.io/controller-runtime/pkg/client"
+	"sigs.k8s.io/controller-runtime/pkg/reconcile"
+
+	"github.com/DataDog/datadog-api-client-go/v2/api/datadogV1"
+
+	"github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/apis/datadoghq/v1alpha1"
+	apiutils "github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/apis/utils"
+	"github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/controllers/finalizer"
+	"github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/controllers/utils"
+	ctrUtils "github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/pkg/controller/utils"
+	"github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/pkg/controller/utils/comparison"
+	"github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/pkg/controller/utils/condition"
+	"github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/pkg/controller/utils/datadog"
+	"github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/pkg/datadogclient"
+)
+
+const (
+	defaultRequeuePeriod    = 60 * time.Second
+	defaultErrRequeuePeriod = 5 * time.Second
+	defaultForceSyncPeriod  = 60 * time.Minute
+	datadogSLOKind          = "DatadogSLO"
+	datadogSLOFinalizer     = "finalizer.slo.datadoghq.com"
+)
+
+type Reconciler struct {
+	client        client.Client
+	datadogClient *datadogV1.ServiceLevelObjectivesApi
+	datadogAuth   context.Context
+	versionInfo   *version.Info
+	log           logr.Logger
+	recorder      record.EventRecorder
+}
+
+func NewReconciler(client client.Client, ddClient datadogclient.DatadogSLOClient, versionInfo *version.Info, log logr.Logger, recorder record.EventRecorder) *Reconciler {
+	return &Reconciler{
+		client:        client,
+		datadogClient: ddClient.Client,
+		datadogAuth:   ddClient.Auth,
+		versionInfo:   versionInfo,
+		log:           log,
+		recorder:      recorder,
+	}
+}
+
+var _ reconcile.Reconciler = (*Reconciler)(nil)
+
+func (r *Reconciler) Reconcile(_ context.Context, req reconcile.Request) (reconcile.Result, error) {
+	res, err := r.internalReconcile(req)
+	return res, err
+}
+
+func (r *Reconciler) internalReconcile(req reconcile.Request) (reconcile.Result, error) {
+	logger := r.log.WithValues("datadogslo", req.NamespacedName)
comment.body: yea I noticed that; I'm not entirely sure why we have this pattern of two loggers but it's present in the DatadogAgent controller as well. when testing I found this logger was a bit more informative to use since it also records the resource name and namespace

This situation has led to complexity in maintaining these `SLOs` with us as well. The introduction of the `DatadogSLO CRD` types and controller into `datadog-operator` aims to simplify this process, enabling us to create and manage our `SLOs` and `Monitors` using our `GitOps` tools. This feature is crucial as we scale and manage a growing number of SLOs across various teams. ### Additional Notes - The development of this feature was inspired by the `DatadogMonitor CRD` codebase, which has proven effective in similar use cases. - Shared Finalizer: A shared finalizer has been added to enhance code reusability. - Simplified Updating Status Conditions: The condition logic has been simplified and now uses Kubernetes utilities for better efficiency and code coverage. ### Describe your test plan Write there any instructions and details you may have to test your PR. - `kind cluster create` - `make buid` - `make IMG=test/operator:test docker-build` - `kubectl apply -f https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/releases/download/v1.8.0/cert-manager.yaml ` - `kind load docker-image test/operator:test` - `make IMG=test/operator:test deploy` - `kubectl apply -f examples/datadogslo/metric-example.yaml` ``` kubectl get datadogslos -n system NAME ID SYNC STATUS AGE example-slo 21e10346c75c5852a12214d1d89dd2c2 OK 2m53s ``` result in DD:

comment.body: @ddjamesfrullo regarding the creation of SLO monitors, maybe we can discuss IRL future plans for the SLO API and if it makes sense to incorporate this behavior in the operator

issue.title: Admission controller port missing from cluster agent deployment
issue.body:
**Output of the info page (if this is a bug)**
```

```

**Describe what happened:**

I recently noticed that none of my service pods were starting after installing the Datadog Operator. After some investigation, I realized there was an issue with the admission controller. In particular, I found the following in the k8s apiserver logs:

```
E1026 06:40:38.020600      11 dispatcher.go:206] failed calling webhook "datadog.webhook.config": failed to call webhook: Post "https://datadog-admission-controller.observability.svc:443/injectconfig?timeout=4s": context deadline exceeded
```

Looking into the configuration, I noticed the the admission service was targeting port 8000 on the cluster agents, but port 8000 was not exposed on the cluster agent deployment.

Looking through the codebase, it doesn't appear that the operator correctly exposes the target port on any pods.

**Describe what you expected:**

I expected the admission webhook to work. It seems like a very big miss given that DataDog is now recommending the operator as the preferred installation method.

The helm chart seems to correctly expose the port: https://github.com/DataDog/helm-charts/blob/cdf0acf8aa46c1884ef7978bfad17c49192caf5c/charts/datadog/templates/cluster-agent-deployment.yaml#L144-L148

**Steps to reproduce the issue:**

Simply run the operator with the cluster agent and admission webhooks enabled (which I believe is the default configuration)

**Additional environment details (Operating System, Cloud provider, etc):**

comment.body:
Turns out I wasn't allow port 8000 traffic from the control plane as mentioned [here](https://docs.datadoghq.com/containers/cluster_agent/admission_controller/?tab=operator#notes).

I'm still surprised it works without exposing the port on the cluster agent though, given that it doesn't seem to be using host networking.

commits.message:
Check CRD status for reconcile errors in upgrade hook (#955)

* Check for reconcile error in upgrade hook

* Fix boolean logic

* Check cluster checks runner reconcile status

pull_request.title: Check CRD status for reconcile errors in upgrade hook
pull_request.body:
### What does this PR do?

Check for agent reconciliation errors in the upgrade hook, and report an error status as appropriate.

### Motivation

There are instances where a reconciliation error occurs in the agent/cluster agent, but the upgrade hook hangs until it times out as it does not detect these errors earlier.

### Additional Notes

Questions: 
1. Should more information be provided in the error that is returned?
2. When testing there was a case where `AgentReconcile` was `false` but `DatadogAgentReconcileError` was `false` as well. To ensure all conditions are covered, the hook currently checks the value of `DatadogAgentReconcileError`, `AgentReconcile` and `ClusterAgentReconcile`, and errors out if any indicate an error state. Is this case valid, or should this be investigated further?

### Minimum Agent Versions

Are there minimum versions of the Datadog Agent and/or Cluster Agent required?

* Agent: vX.Y.Z
* Cluster Agent: vX.Y.Z

### Describe your test plan

1. Set up the operator to deploy the agent
2. Build the `check-operator` CLI: `cd /cmd/check-operator && go build .` 
4. Verify that when there are no issues with deployment, no error is reported by the upgrade hook `./check-operator upgrade datadog` 
5. Try to deploy the agent in a way that will cause a reconciliation error e.g. having a label that is too long
```
apiVersion: datadoghq.com/v2alpha1
kind: DatadogAgent
metadata:
  name: datadog
spec:
  global:
    credentials:
      apiSecret:
        secretName: datadog-secret
        keyName: api-key
      appSecret:
        secretName: datadog-secret
        keyName: app-key
  override:
    nodeAgent:
      labels:
        too-long: sdfjkhsdjfhkjsdhfljkhsdkjfhgkshfjkhwejkfhjkwehflkwehkjfskjhfgkjshfkhskjdghfkjsdhgkjsdhlgkjlksjfgkjsdklgjsdlkjgfdjslkdsjfkljsdklfjlkdsjflksdjfklsjdklfjsdlkfjlksdjf
  features:
    apm:
      enabled: true
    logCollection:
      enabled: true
```
6. Verify that when running the upgrade hook, an error is reported (`got reconcile error`)

I couldn't find existing tests for the hook, but if I had missed it happy to add unit tests to cover these changes!!

### Checklist

- [ ] PR has at least one valid label: `bug`, `enhancement`, `refactoring`, `documentation`, `tooling`, and/or `dependencies`
- [ ] PR has a milestone or the `qa/skip-qa` label

issue.title: Adding Service Level Objective CRD and Controller

labels.name: editorial review
labels.description: Waiting on a more in-depth review

issue.body: ### What does this PR do? This pull request introduces the `DatadogSLO CRD` types and controller, addressing issue #684. ### Motivation As each organization scales, they gonna rely on many `SLOs`, each of the SLO's managed by individual teams. This situation has led to complexity in maintaining these `SLOs` with us as well. The introduction of the `DatadogSLO CRD` types and controller into `datadog-operator` aims to simplify this process, enabling us to create and manage our `SLOs` and `Monitors` using our `GitOps` tools. This feature is crucial as we scale and manage a growing number of SLOs across various teams. ### Additional Notes - The development of this feature was inspired by the `DatadogMonitor CRD` codebase, which has proven effective in similar use cases. - Shared Finalizer: A shared finalizer has been added to enhance code reusability. - Simplified Updating Status Conditions: The condition logic has been simplified and now uses Kubernetes utilities for better efficiency and code coverage. ### Describe your test plan Write there any instructions and details you may have to test your PR. - `kind cluster create` - `make buid` - `make IMG=test/operator:test docker-build` - `kubectl apply -f https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/releases/download/v1.8.0/cert-manager.yaml ` - `kind load docker-image test/operator:test` - `make IMG=test/operator:test deploy` - `kubectl apply -f examples/datadogslo/metric-example.yaml` ``` kubectl get datadogslos -n system NAME ID SYNC STATUS AGE example-slo 21e10346c75c5852a12214d1d89dd2c2 OK 2m53s ``` result in DD:

comment.body: I read the comments here about how to handle dependency. I think without dependency handling, monitor SLOs are not really useful to have here. At the same time, I'm happy with that because we want to move away from monitor SLOs. We're about to release a new type called time-slice SLOs that will allow you to create an uptime SLO directly from metrics. We can talk about how to add that here when the time is right. About creating SLO monitors (like burn rate and error budget monitors), it's an interesting idea to specify those monitors along with SLO details at creation time. Would it make sense, then, to hit both the SLO API and the monitor API in the implementation of the operator? Or were you thinking about having our SLO create API allow for monitor creation? I would prefer the latter.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+apiVersion: datadoghq.com/v1alpha1
+kind: DatadogSLO
+metadata:
+  name: example-slo
+  namespace: system 
+spec:
+  name: example-slo
+  description: "This is an example SLO from datadog-operator"
+  query:
+    denominator: "sum:requests.total{service:example,env:prod}.as_count()"
comment.body: What if we use `numerator: "sum:universal.http.server.hits{service:example, env:prod, !http.status_class:5xx}.as_count()"` and `denominator: sum:universal.http.server.hits{service:example, env:prod}.as_count()"` instead of `requests.total`  and `request.success` as the default metrics? It's a bit more complicated, but if they have universal service monitoring, at least that stands a chance of working when they replace it with their service. If they don't have universal service monitoring, then at least we're advertising a Datadog product. Not a big deal to keep these defaults, though.

Update bundle examples config to include DatadogAgent v2alpha1 (#957)

pull_request.title: Update bundle examples config to include DatadogAgent v2alpha1
pull_request.body:
### What does this PR do?

Update bundle examples config to include alm examples for the `DatadogAgent/v2alpha1` CRD to reflect the current latest version.

### Motivation

The current bundle CSV examples don't include examples for the `v2alpha1`, only `v1alpha` of the `DatadogAgent` CRD. 

### Additional Notes

Previewing the `clusterserviceversion.yaml` file using https://operatorhub.io/preview currently shows the `v1alpha1` example for both CRD versions. I made a bug report: https://github.com/k8s-operatorhub/operatorhub.io/issues/56

### Minimum Agent Versions

Are there minimum versions of the Datadog Agent and/or Cluster Agent required?

* Agent: vX.Y.Z
* Cluster Agent: vX.Y.Z

### Describe your test plan

Run `make VERSION=1.2.1 bundle` and confirm that the `v2alpha1` example is included in the `bundle/manifests/datadog-operator.clusterserviceversion.yaml` file. 

### Checklist

- [x] PR has at least one valid label: `bug`, `enhancement`, `refactoring`, `documentation`, `tooling`, and/or `dependencies`
- [x] PR has a milestone or the `qa/skip-qa` label

issue.title: `kubectl get datadogagent` has stale status
issue.body:
When we run `kubectl get datadogagent`, we get this output. It seems stale from inspecting the JSON version:

```shell
$ kubectl get datadogagent
NAME      AGENT              CLUSTER-AGENT    CLUSTER-CHECKS-RUNNER   AGE
datadog   Updating (4/0/0)   Failed (1/0/1)   Failed                  20h
$ kubectl get datadogagent datadog -o json | jq .status
{
  "agent": {
    "available": 0,
    "current": 0,
    "currentHash": "c9897059e0f650f03297871abd9c03aa",
    "daemonsetName": "datadog-agent",
    "desired": 4,
    "lastUpdate": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
    "ready": 0,
    "state": "Updating",
    "status": "Updating (4/0/0)",
    "upToDate": 0
  },
  "clusterAgent": {
    "currentHash": "ded17fe49f0e805d4c9905d213ea5ca2",
    "deploymentName": "datadog-cluster-agent",
    "generatedToken": "[...]",
    "lastUpdate": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
    "replicas": 1,
    "state": "Failed",
    "status": "Failed (1/0/1)",
    "unavailableReplicas": 2,
    "updatedReplicas": 1
  },
  "clusterChecksRunner": {
    "state": "Failed",
    "status": "Failed"
  },
  "conditions": [
    {
      "lastTransitionTime": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
      "message": "Deployment updated",
      "reason": "UpdateSucceeded",
      "status": "True",
      "type": "ClusterAgentReconcile"
    },
    {
      "lastTransitionTime": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
      "message": "DatadogAgent reconcile error",
      "reason": "DatadogAgent_reconcile_error",
      "status": "True",
      "type": "DatadogAgentReconcileError"
    },
    {
      "lastTransitionTime": "2023-08-29T13:40:48Z",
      "message": "Datadog metrics forwarding ok",
      "reason": "MetricsForwardingSucceeded",
      "status": "True",
      "type": "ActiveDatadogMetrics"
    },
    {
      "lastTransitionTime": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
      "message": "Daemonset updated",
      "reason": "UpdateSucceeded",
      "status": "True",
      "type": "AgentReconcile"
    },
    {
      "lastTransitionTime": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
      "message": "Unable to update Deployment",
      "reason": "UpdateSucceeded",
      "status": "False",
      "type": "ClusterChecksRunnerReconcile"
    }
  ]
}
```

The actual agent deployments etc. look fine:

```shell
$ kubectl get pod | grep agent
datadog-agent-7wnqs                              3/3     Running   0          20h
datadog-agent-g4d42                              3/3     Running   0          20h
datadog-agent-qfz6b                              3/3     Running   0          20h
datadog-agent-tv7jn                              3/3     Running   0          20h
datadog-cluster-agent-56f45dfbfd-hwlxt           1/1     Running   0          20h
```

**Steps to reproduce the issue:**

I installed the Datadog Operator following https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/blob/main/docs/installation.md using the OLM instructions.

**Additional environment details (Operating System, Cloud provider, etc):**

We're running on GKE, version 1.26.5-gke.1200.

https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/issues/93 looks similar but was closed several years ago.

comment.body: Great to hear, appreciate the update @smcgivern

```shell
  },
```

```shell
    "currentHash": "ded17fe49f0e805d4c9905d213ea5ca2",
    "deploymentName": "datadog-cluster-agent",
    "generatedToken": "[...]",
    "lastUpdate": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
    "replicas": 1,
    "state": "Failed",
    "status": "Failed (1/0/1)",
    "unavailableReplicas": 2,
    "updatedReplicas": 1
  },
  "clusterChecksRunner": {
    "state": "Failed",
    "status": "Failed"
  },
  "conditions": [
    {
      "lastTransitionTime": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
      "message": "Deployment updated",
      "reason": "UpdateSucceeded",
      "status": "True",
      "type": "ClusterAgentReconcile"
    },
    {
      "lastTransitionTime": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
      "message": "DatadogAgent reconcile error",
      "reason": "DatadogAgent_reconcile_error",
      "status": "True",
      "type": "DatadogAgentReconcileError"
    },
    {
      "lastTransitionTime": "2023-08-29T13:40:48Z",
      "message": "Datadog metrics forwarding ok",
      "reason": "MetricsForwardingSucceeded",
      "status": "True",
      "type": "ActiveDatadogMetrics"
    },
    {
      "lastTransitionTime": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
      "message": "Daemonset updated",
      "reason": "UpdateSucceeded",
      "status": "True",
      "type": "AgentReconcile"
    },
    {
      "lastTransitionTime": "2023-08-29T13:40:49Z",
      "message": "Unable to update Deployment",
      "reason": "UpdateSucceeded",
      "status": "False",
      "type": "ClusterChecksRunnerReconcile"
    }
  ]
}
```

The actual agent deployments etc. look fine:

```shell
$ kubectl get pod | grep agent
datadog-agent-7wnqs                              3/3     Running   0          20h
datadog-agent-g4d42                              3/3     Running   0          20h
datadog-agent-qfz6b                              3/3     Running   0          20h
datadog-agent-tv7jn                              3/3     Running   0          20h
datadog-cluster-agent-56f45dfbfd-hwlxt           1/1     Running   0          20h
```

**Steps to reproduce the issue:**

I installed the Datadog Operator following https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/blob/main/docs/installation.md using the OLM instructions.

**Additional environment details (Operating System, Cloud provider, etc):**

We're running on GKE, version 1.26.5-gke.1200.

https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/issues/93 looks similar but was closed several years ago.

comment.body: Support helped us fix this! We had a RoleBinding left over from our previous (non-operator) install. Running `kubectl delete rolebinding datadog-cluster-agent -n default` fixed it, as the operator was able to recreate the binding and have the right permissions.

issue.title: Pod Disruption Budget isn't created for cluster agent
issue.body:
**Output of the info page (if this is a bug)**
```
❯ k get datadogagents.datadoghq.com
NAME      AGENT             CLUSTER-AGENT     CLUSTER-CHECKS-RUNNER   AGE
datadog   Running (4/4/4)   Running (2/2/2)                           76d

❯ k get pdb -A | rg cluster

```

**Describe what happened:**
If the replica count is above 1, then PDB should be created according to this logic: https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-operator/blob/2b77d724bd06c256106fe45c54f9a90ddaa2fb8b/controllers/datadogagent/poddisruptionbudget.go#L40

However, maybe because the apiVersion changed on the agent, it's not creating PDBs.

**Describe what you expected:**
PDB for cluster agent to be created

**Steps to reproduce the issue:**
Scale up replica of cluster agent to 2.

**Additional environment details (Operating System, Cloud provider, etc):**

comment.body: Coming from the helm chart installation method, I noticed this was missing too.

pull_request.title: Update bundle examples config to include DatadogAgent v2alpha1
pull_request.body:
### What does this PR do?

Update bundle examples config to include alm examples for the `DatadogAgent/v2alpha1` CRD to reflect the current latest version.

### Motivation

The current bundle CSV examples don't include examples for the `v2alpha1`, only `v1alpha` of the `DatadogAgent` CRD. 

### Additional Notes

Anything else we should know when reviewing?

### Minimum Agent Versions

Are there minimum versions of the Datadog Agent and/or Cluster Agent required?

* Agent: vX.Y.Z
* Cluster Agent: vX.Y.Z

### Describe your test plan

Run `make VERSION=1.2.1 bundle` and confirm that the `v2alpha1` example is included in the `bundle/manifests/datadog-operator.clusterserviceversion.yaml` file. 

### Checklist

- [x] PR has at least one valid label: `bug`, `enhancement`, `refactoring`, `documentation`, `tooling`, and/or `dependencies`
- [x] PR has a milestone or the `qa/skip-qa` label
